Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks tumbling over each other, a silent accusation. My wife’s voice echoes in my mind, gentle but firm: “Can you please help fold these before we leave?” I know she’s been juggling work and chores all week, and I promised I’d do my part. But today is also the day of the family puja—my parents have called twice already, reminding me to be on time, to wear my kurta, to bring sweets for the offering. The ceremony is important, a tradition that binds us, and I can’t be late. My heart pounds as I glance at the clock, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. If I stay to help, we’ll be late for the puja and my family will be disappointed. If I leave now, the laundry will sit, another broken promise to my wife. I stand frozen, torn between the expectations of a good husband and a dutiful son, wishing I could be in two places at once.
